body: MOST kitchen equipment is purchased with the task in mind: you want a tool that works easily and efficiently. So it is rare to come across a tool like the nutcracker, which is used both for the task and for the pleasure of breaking open a nut and retrieving the meat. Nuts straight from the shell have much more flavor than those bought shelled, so
title: TEST KITCHEN; Romancing the Nut: First, Get It Open

body: To the Editor: Re ''Disparate Visions for New Park'' (news article, Dec. 12): An assumption in the debate regarding the character of the proposed Brooklyn Bridge Park seems to be that the park must be homogeneous from end to end. In an arc extending for miles, why can't each part of the park reflect the character of the adjacent neighborhood: a
title: A Park for All

body: The felt-tipped marker in Michel Trocme's hand sped across the easel, leaving an orange trail of ideas as the 30 people sitting around him each outlined a different vision of what kind of park to build at the foot of the Brooklyn Bridge. Nathan F. Elbogen, 38, a Gowanus artist and architect with a shaved head, rose to say he wanted studios and a
title: Disparate Visions for a New Park; Accord Is Sought Among Clashing Views in Brooklyn

body: For years, John Jay High School, on Seventh Avenue near Fourth Street, has been troubled, ranking high among the city's schools in assaults and robberies and low in test scores and graduation rates. John Jay is situated in the prosperous heart of Park Slope, but many parents there never dreamed of sending their children to the school. The local
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROWNSTONE BROOKLYN; School Board May Try to Take Over Troubled John Jay

body: Kozmo.com, the Internet company that has made a reputation for itself by promising to deliver movie videotapes, ice cream and snacks to New Yorkers within an hour, is taking steps to broaden its offerings and quicken its delivery time. The company, which has two warehouses in Manhattan, is planning to open a third on Varick Street in TriBeCa on
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: TRIBECA; Feeding the Appetite for Videos and Snacks, Ever Faster

title: PUBLIC LIVES

title: COPING; The Mentally Ill Emerge From the Shadows

body: Healing With Music TUESDAY -- The singer Phil Collins and his manager, Tony Smith, will be honored for their support of the Nordoff-Robbins Music Therapy Foundation, which uses music to treat children with a wide variety of physical and emotional disabilities, at a dinner at Roseland, 239 West 52d Street. title: BENEFITS

body: BY some accounts, the house on New Rochelle's Van Meter Fenway was a mess, the sort of home that should have gone for a relative pittance to anyone who was ready to stomach perhaps $100,000 in repairs. title: The Market: Inventory Down, Prices Up

body: In Flatbush, Brooklyn, a woman whose six-room house has been revamped into a nursery for 10 children takes in only half that number most days. Near Yankee Stadium in the Bronx, a former day-care worker who has filled her living room with books, building blocks and a computer has managed to recruit only one 4-year-old girl into her care. On the
title: Openings Go Unfilled as City Officials Plan How to Spend Day-Care Money

body: Sitting on their mothers' laps, six small children wait quietly in a second-floor schoolroom on the Upper East Side. The oldest child is 2; the youngest just turned 1. One sucks his thumb. Another plays with her belly button. Class is about to start. ''Si, quien esta aqui?'' asks Veronica Noguera, a youthful teacher with a furry puppet on each
title: To Talk Like New York, Sign Up for Spanish

body: A former cheese warehouse in the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn has been converted into the Mary McDowell Center for Learning, a private, 101-pupil Quaker school for 5- to 12-year-old learning disabled children. The 17,500-square-foot, four-story late 19th-century brick structure at 20 Bergen Street, near Court Street, was gutted and all systems,
title: POSTINGS: Quakers Transform Brooklyn Cheese Warehouse; A School for Learning Disabled

body: Akshay Ganesh, a 12-year-old seventh grader who lives on Staten Island, rolls out of bed every weekday about 6 A.M. He has 20 minutes to eat breakfast and get dressed before heading out the door to catch the S66 bus to catch the 7 A.M. ferry to Manhattan. Swimming in a sea of suits, briefcases and crumpled newspapers, he tries to avoid dozing off
title: To Middle School, by Bus, Subway and Ferry

body: Surrounded by their bath products, which are beaded and bedecked with the paper parasols seen on tropical drinks, the two entrepreneurs talked business strategy in their Cobble Hill testing lab. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROWNSTONE BROOKLYN; To Young Tycoons, Bathtime Is an Opportunity, Not a Chore

body: Teresa Cama, a lifelong resident of Red Hook, Brooklyn, stood outside her home on Visitation Place and recalled the days when the long-vacant brick building across the street was a Roman Catholic elementary school. She graduated from the eighth grade at Visitation School a half-century ago. Two of her children graduated from the school, and another
title: Court Is Moving Back Into the Neighborhood

body: Southern restaurants occupy a quiet but flourishing niche in New York. Here are a dozen of the best examples. body: Suzanne Michelle Levin and Pedro Morales were married last evening aboard the Excalibur Yacht in the North Cove Yacht Harbor in Manhattan. Lisel Burns, the leader of the Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture, performed the ceremony. Ms. Levin, 33, is keeping her name. She is the director for client services of the Medicare Rights Center, a nonprofit
title: WEDDINGS; Pedro Morales, Suzanne Levin

body: Morrells to Add Wine Bar At Rockefeller Center Site Morrell & Company, one of New York's top wine shops, has shed its clubby look in moving from Madison Avenue to Rockefeller Center. title: FOOD STUFF

body: The Music Stopped Q. I've heard that a place called Telharmonic Hall once existed in Manhattan. What was it? A. Telharmonic Hall, which was built in 1906 at the northeast corner of 39th Street and Broadway, represented the apogee of an ambitious and quixotic musical vision dreamed up by an Iowan named Thaddeus Cahill. Ken Smith tells Mr. Cahill's
title: F.Y.I.

body: Pupils returning to schools in Brooklyn's District 15 next month may find first graders reading in what was formerly a computer lab or art studio. On Wednesday evening, the district's community school board passed a resolution to limit all first-grade classes to 20 pupils. Mark Peters, the board's president, said he believed his board was first in
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; With Cut in Class Size, a District Improvises With Space

body: To the Editor: Your July 4 article [''Homes Built to Instill Pride in Ownership''] may leave the impression that almost all of Habitat of Humanity's efforts in New York City are directed toward the rehabilitation of existing housing units. In fact, development plans for the immediate future include substantial new construction, primarily consisting
title: New Construction Of Habitat Homes

body: How interesting that Spike Lee admits to encountering almost no racism during his childhood in an integrated Cobble Hill, Brooklyn (June 27). One might conclude, therefore, that his professional gruel of hip-hop culture and racialist politics is an exclusively ideological posture and perhaps even a self-serving career decision. But give Lee his
title: New Kid on The Block

body: Q: We know what Son of Sam did in the summer of 1977. What did you do? title: The Way We Live Now: 6-27-99: Questions for Spike Lee; New Kid on the Block

body: IN the days when the Gowanus Canal was best known for its foul odors, it would not have come to mind quickly as a site for an upscale shopping center. title: Commercial Property /Brooklyn; At Gowanus Canal, Developers Plan $63 Million Mall

body: The instructions for the English test taken this year by all New York fourth graders included ''check your work.'' title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARK SLOPE/COBBLE HILL; It's Not Just Kids Who Flunk Spelling

body: To most New Yorkers, the little-used stretch of Brooklyn waterfront between the mighty stanchions of the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges is the stuff of faded picture postcards, vaguely recalling a majestic past but hardly worth the trip. With its abandoned Civil War-era warehouses, its cobblestone streets and a tiny state park, the area, known as
title: Unveiling a Bold Vision for Brooklyn's Waterfront

body: BEYOND the plusher precincts of Manhattan, New York City's co-op and condominium market has been steadily gaining strength, bringing welcome financial news and a palpable sense of relief to many apartment owners. The market had been dormant, if not on life support, for the first half of this decade. Those were the bad old days: a time when promises
title: Troubled Co-ops Outside Manhattan Are on the Rebound

body: For Ana Reyes, running Ana's Opus, the store she opened two weeks ago at 224 Smith Street between Douglass and Degraw Streets in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, is a way to pay the bills during retirement while fulfilling a lifelong passion. ''I've always enjoyed finding interesting and beautiful things,'' she said. Now she's assembled those found objects,
title: NEW YORKERS & CO.; Like an Old Studio Apartment With Everything for Sale

body: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani signed legislation yesterday that makes it illegal for the city to force homeless families to sleep on the floor of its emergency assistance office. The law, sponsored by Councilman Stephen DiBrienza of Brooklyn, also requires that the Emergency Assistance Unit in the Bronx remain open 24 hours a day. It also establishes
title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK; Law Effects Changes In Treatment of Homeless

body: Take pity on the next generation of music fiends, for they may not know the pleasure of loitering in little record stores. People in their 20's, 30's and 40's, less and less guilty about shopping on the Internet, are regularly denying themselves the chance to go into a record shop and just look. In their defense, they complain that the clerks don't
title: Stalking That Rare Recording

body: A little bit of Venice in Brooklyn? That was the question at Brooklyn's Gowanus Canal yesterday as city officials finally got around to activating a plumbing fixture that will allow the canal to be flushed of the rancid liquids that give the waterway its famous stench. The fixture -- a new propeller to circulate the stagnant water and diminish its
title: Finally, Flushing an Infamous Canal

body: Last August, Mark Phillips set up a Web site to pay homage to the Gowanus Canal and to show off his photographs of its floating basketballs, bodies and even store facades. To his surprise, he said, the site attracted foreigners fascinated by the two-and-a-half mile stretch of fetid water, many of whom told Mr. Phillips they hoped to tour the canal
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK ON LINE; Click on the Corner Store

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN AND QUEENS UP CLOSE; Modern, and Unwelcome in Historic Areas

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK ONLINE; When Latin Pride Took to the Streets

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN WATERFRONT; A 'Garbage Summit' and a Call to Arms

title: In All 5 Boroughs, A Robust Market

body: Walk along Court Street in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, and you can now find two Harvest restaurants. Harvest serves southern American comfort food, and Harvest
title: NEW YORKERS & CO.; At Two Sites, Comfort Food That Spans the Globe

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE

body: New Age Takeout, Ever So Subtle The new spa-style W Hotel, 541 Lexington Avenue (49th Street), is a fit location for Cool Juice, a bright little takeout spot with its own street entrance. No overt health-food philosophy drives the menu, but supplement blends, said to be healing or memory-enhancing, can be added to drinks, and there's an emphasis on
title: FOOD STUFF

body: ONE of the dangers with interviewing Sean Kelly is that you might find out what your name means, if it happens to be Irish. (From the Gaelic, Kelly translates as something like ''sacred prostitute.'' Kennedy means ''ugly head.'') You will also probably hear more than you want about the Irish saint whose day this is: first of all, he was not Irish
title: PUBLIC LIVES; When Irish Eyes Are Smiling Maliciously

body: A control room fire on the F and G subway lines in Brooklyn on Thursday night destroyed critical switching equipment, forcing transportation officials to close five stations and disrupt service yesterday for more than 150,000 passengers in several Brooklyn neighborhoods. Officials of New York City Transit said last night that most service would be
title: After Station Fire, Subway Lines Face Months of Turmoil

author: Douglas Century is the author of ''Street Kingdom: Five Years Inside the Franklin Avenue Posse,'' recently published by Warner Books.
body: On a recent March morning, I walked the windy piers of the Brooklyn waterfront, gazing out at the choppy waters of Buttermilk Channel and Upper New York Bay, looking for the shadow of my grandfather. He had fled conscription into the Czar's army in 1914, landed at Ellis Island and found work as a longshoreman on the docks of what was then one of
title: MY BROOKLYN; Still a Contender on the Waterfront

body: WEINSTEIN-Robert B. Congregation Baith Israel Anshei Emes (The Kane Street Synagogue) mourns the untimely death of its beloved member, treasurer, past president, ritual leader, teacher, and friend. Our loss of this good and gentle leader, steadfast and true to one and all, is profound. The funeral service will be held at noon on Sunday, March 7, at
title: Paid Notice: Deaths WEINSTEIN, ROBERT B.

body: WEINSTEIN-Robert B. On March 4, 1999. Loving son of Blanche and Herbert A. Dear brother of Laurie Besmertnik. Brother-in-law of Sid. Dear uncle of Bonnie, Todd and Sara. body: Almost three years ago, when Sarah Lichtman and Rachel Kueny opened Astro Turf, a boutique of 1950's bric-a-brac at 290 Smith Street, neighbors didn't get it. ''So they'd bring us their junk -- like old stoves,'' Ms. Lichtman said. Astro Turf is no longer an anomaly on Smith Street. In recent months, the nondescript four-block row straddling Cobble
title: PULSE; A Street Grows in Brooklyn

body: To the Editor: Ready, aim, fire! Yes, I am a member of a community school board and I know I have to duck to avoid being knocked down by the usual torrent of accusations, that I'm a political hack or a patronage source. The school board image has been so bad that even my children look at me funny when anyone mentions school boards. This is
title: Serving on School Board Is Worth the Headaches

body: New York City schools are facing a growing shortage of principals, driven by competition from higher-paying suburbs, the stress of dealing with a proliferation of new tests and the impending retirement of large numbers of current administrators, according to a report released yesterday by a nonprofit advocacy group. The shortage is part of a
title: New York City Is Facing Shortage of Principals, Report Finds

body: The regulars at Montero Bar on Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn Heights say they do not usually drive before or after they take their drinks. Joseph and Tony call a car service, while the bartenders, Carol and Linda, always walk home. They all condemn drunken driving, but yesterday they reserved their fiercest condemnation for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
title: On Bar Stools, Giuliani Plan Is Scorned

A perfumed, almost autumnal sensation fills the mouth, like the scent of sunshine-dried leaves, butterscotch and toasted nuts. Then the featherweight cake
title: TEMPTATION; Like a Bee to Madeleines

body: Donald Pye's ocher-tipped fingers stubbed an unfiltered Pall Mall into the ashtray he keeps clipped to his wheelchair at the Cobble Hill Health Center, a nursing home in Brooklyn. ''The President says he wants to raise the price of cigarettes another 55 cents,'' said Mr. Pye, who has already seen the price for a pack of Pall Malls jump to $3.60,
title: Clinging to an Ever Dearer Habit; People of Meager Means Find Ways to Keep Smoking

body: City officials assured a judge yesterday that they would not immediately evict five community programs from a building in Brooklyn where Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani wants to put a homeless shelter. Judge Cheryl E. Chambers of State Supreme Court said she expected to hold a hearing next week on the dispute between the city and the community agencies
title: No Evictions for Now in Feud On Homeless Shelter, City Says

body: With four community agencies in Brooklyn facing eviction as early as tomorrow, the City Council is in last-minute negotiations with the Giuliani administration to avert that showdown and to resolve broader policy disputes over the city's homeless shelters. Asked about the chances of a settlement, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said at a news conference
title: Mayor and Council Negotiate on Shelters as Agencies Await Eviction

body: LINDA BLYER is not the kind of person who fights City Hall. She is a former home economics teacher who speaks so softly people lean in to hear her. Her only previous encounter with city government was in 1976, when she was enlisted as a quilting instructor during the Bicentennial celebration. ''I'm embarrassed to admit it,'' she said last week,
title: A Quiet Voice Raised Against City Hall

body: For more than a year, the Giuliani administration has quietly moved to shut down the city's largest homeless shelter, and city officials have been meeting with representatives of a for-profit company that wants to establish an upscale assisted-living residence for the elderly in the East Side building. One of the lobbyists for the developer is Suri
title: Questions Clouding Future Of Men's Shelter at Bellevue

body: As the Giuliani administration presses its plan to evict several community programs from a Brooklyn building to make way for a homeless shelter, city mechanics inspected the building yesterday to determine if it was suitable for such a use. title: Mayor Presses Plan for Brooklyn Homeless Center

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WESTERN BROOKLYN; District Says School Construction Numbers Don't Add Up

title: The Rudy Giuliani Wars; Vengeance in Brooklyn

body: Barry Turner lives alone in a fifth-floor walkup on a quiet street in the Prospect Heights section of Brooklyn. He's a nervous man. Fidgets all the time. title: In America; The Politics of Cruelty

body: To the Editor: By ordering that a homeless shelter be set up in a city-owned building in the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn (editorial, Jan. 4), Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is reversing the optimism of those who live in the neighborhood. Brooklyn is turning into a wonderful place to live. Responsibility for services like homeless shelters, jails,
title: Mayor Puts the Defenseless Into the Crossfire

body: More than 500 people gathered at a Brooklyn synagogue last night for a forum where local politicians detailed strategies that they hope will persuade Mayor Rudolph W. Guiliani to rescind his decision to put a homeless shelter in their neighborhood. City Councilman Stephen DiBrienza, who represents the Cobble Hill neighborhood, called on local
title: Critics Gather To Fight Plans For a Shelter

body: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's war with the New York City Council on homeless shelters has led the administration to serve an eviction notice on a Brooklyn community psychiatric center that serves 500 mentally ill outpatients. That was a peculiar way to celebrate the holiday season. It is also dreadful policy making that should be allowed to die with the
title: A Resolution for the Mayor

body: Three years ago, Alan Alpert's son, John, then 4, was having trouble speaking and understanding in preschool. School officials, Mr. Alpert said, suggested he enroll his son in the private Mary McDowell School for Learning, which specializes in teaching the learning disabled.
